content.description: Start in the perfect cavey hole under the roof. Stand start on the triangular jug with feet on the wall. Slap your way out with bad feet to the sloper rail mantel. Finish up and left for a easy/spicy topout, or end after you mantel to a stand on the rail.
content.location:
It is a 3 minute walk, north, past the Electric Butterfly shed. The boulder is about 6 feet from the trail on the left, just past the "

Fifth Base

" black face.

content.description: Sit start matched on a low undercling. Move up through the overhung scoop to the lip. Wrestle with the bulging lip and arete for the top out.
content.protection: Three pads are ideal since the movement wanders and the landing is an ankle breaker with rocks and holes.
content.location: About 40 yards up the creek from the obvious cave boulder. It's defined by a big scoop/dihedral and sits next to the creek. Easy to see from the trail.

content.description: Start crouched with your left hand in a triangular jug pocket thing and your right hand on a side pull sloper. Use crimps to climb straight up the overhanging face to a committing throw for the lip. The movement is great, and you can safely work the lower portion, but if you blow the move to the lip you could be in for the ride of your life.
content.location: This is across the creek about halfway up the hill, towards the south side of the Jumble Buttress. It is an obvious wave of granite in a prominent position among the tiers and talus, and it sits above the wreckage of the old cart tracks. The "barrel" of the wave faces uphill, so it is hard to spot from down on the trail.

content.description: There are three routes on this decent piece of rock. The farthest left goes as V0-1 if you don't stem out to the rock to the left. The middle on goes at V1, and the far right I haven't climbed because it was soaking wet.
content.protection: Pads, they top out kinda high.
content.location:
This is right off the side of the road past

Electric Butterfly

.

content.description: This is on the boulder next to the river. There is a pretty good landing. The crux is one large bodylength reach to more good holds. I just recently clean some moss and dirt, so it's good to climb.
content.location: This is on the huge boulder next to the river. There is a small cave-ish thing with water coming out of the boulder downstream of this project. There are also a couple projects in the cave, your shoes get wet....

content.description:
This is the right-to-left version of

the traverse

. This direction is slightly more difficult. Start with hands matched on an obvious hold about chest high on the southwest face and make a fun move to a sloper sidepull. Finagle your way around the arete (crux) and do a tricky traverse to the left with sometimes non-existent footholds. Finish in the big pod far left for the send.
content.protection: Maybe a pad, but it's low.
content.location:
This is on the obvious roadside boulder near the building just upstream from

Electric Butterfly

and

Lost Dog

.

content.description:
Scramble up and start in the horizontal crack. Climb straight up the tall, overhanging face and arete using gaston crimps and arete pinches. Top out directly up the arete on to the upper slab.

There is also a much easier/safer variation that immediately turns the arete corner and climbs rails up the alcove.
content.protection:
The landing is rocky and drops away sharply for ~25'. I built up a couple of logs and anchored one of my pads with a blue tricam, but a fall would be serious no matter how many pads you have.

An anchor can be set up ~30' back from the lip for a rappel or top rope (#0.75, 1, & 2 C4).
content.location: Across the creek from the trail and about 80 yards downstream of the large cave boulder. It is best to walk over the bridge and double back over the talus. It faces slightly upstream in a sort of alcove, but it is easily seen from the trail if you are looking for it.

content.description:
Stand start with your left hand on an undercling sloper and your right hand on the arete using a pinch. Climb directly up the arete.

Rose Weaver variation starts the same but peels left of the arete and tops out up the small face.
content.location:
Upstream of

Smile from a Veil

and about 50 yards downstream of the bridge, the boulder sits in/on the edge of creek and is easily visible from the trail. Walk across the bridge, and double back on the other side of the creek. The boulder will be about 20 yards below you and is accessed by walking down through the talus.

content.description: Start low where the black rock meets the white with your right hand on a sharp crimp and your left hand on a gaston, fingerlocky feature. Work up and left through nice rock on cool crimp ledges, traversing into less quality rock with an easy section halfway, to the topout up the hill on the left. Bring a spotter or bunch of pads.
content.protection:
It is traversy, so bring multiple pads or

quality

spotters.
content.location: About two to three minute walk, north, up the trail from the Electric Butterfly building, the boulder almost touches the trail, on the left side.

content.description:
Start by hugging the arete using two opposing micro-crimp sidepulls (around navel height). Move straight up until you can pull onto the upper slab and top out.

It is only climbable during low water in the fall or winter.
content.location:
Upstream of

Smile from a Veil

and about 50 yards downstream of the bridge. The boulder sits in/on the edge of creek and is easily visible from the trail. Walk across the bridge and double back on the other side of the creek. The boulder will be about 20 yards below you and is accessed by walking down through the talus.

content.description:
Stand start matched on the half-moon side pull in the middle of the slab. Climb straight up and slightly left using a variety of holds to tackle the steepest, most blank part of the boulder.

There are a few, fun variations.
content.location: At the top of the first hill past the gate, roughly 80 yards beyond the metal-roofed shed on the left, the boulder sits next to the creek down the steep embankment (the same side as the trail). It is mostly obscured by vegetation, but you can make out the top of it from the trail above. Stick to the areas where fishermen have already created rough paths down to the creek to avoid further erosion.

content.description:
This is a worthy little distraction from the other No Name climbs or maybe it could be a warm-up or cool down for a day of trad climbing. Start on the far left of the boulder's south face in a pod or with hands matched on the leaning arete (not to be confused with and to the left of the left-angling crack). Traverse right all the way to the southeast face and top out. This climb has tricky footwork as the rock is deceptively slippery.

Edit: After climbing this again, I decided to upgrade it to V2. I think that is more accurate considering some of the cryptic beta and tricky footwork.
content.protection: A pad and a spotter for the topout.
content.location:
This is on the roadside boulder just upstream of

Electric Butterfly

and

Lost Dog

.
